titleStmt.title: Selectæ aliquot legum atque ordinationum academicanum particulæ quas D. Procancellarius quò magìs hoc seculo ad neglectum aut desuetudinem vergere videntur, eò impensiùs à singulis (pro suo cujusque loco atque officio) observandas proponit, in virtute juramenti, & sub pœna quæ incumbit transgressoribus.
titleStmt.author: University of Cambridge.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

Images scanned from microfilm: (Early English books, 1475-1640 ; 1849:13)

titleStmt.title: Selectæ aliquot legum atque ordinationum academicanum particulæ quas D. Procancellarius quò magìs hoc seculo ad neglectum aut desuetudinem vergere videntur, eò impensiùs à singulis (pro suo cujusque loco atque officio) observandas proponit, in virtute juramenti, & sub pœna quæ incumbit transgressoribus.
titleStmt.author: University of Cambridge.

notesStmt.note: Date defaced and replaced with "Jan. 7. 1630"; date of publication suggested by STC (2nd ed.).
Reproduction of original in the University of Cambridge. Archives.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2007-08 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2007-09 Elspeth HealeyText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: ¶ Selectae aliquot legum atque ordinationum Academicarum particulae, quas D. Procancellarius, quò magis hoc ſeculo ad neglectum aut deſuetudinem vergere videntur, eò impenſiùs à ſingulis (pro ſuo cujuſque loco atque officio) obſervandas proponit, in virtute juramenti, & ſub poena quae incumbit tranſgreſſoribus.
div.p: 1 SCholares omnes modeſtiam omnibus in locis colant: inferiores ſuperioribus loco cedant, & debitâ reverentiâ proſequantur.
2 In templis ſcholiſque nemo auſit ſedilia conſcendere, nemo in publicis exercitiis indecorum ſtrepitum edere, pedibus pulſando, pluteos caedendo, cachinnando, ſibilando, aut indecenter excreando.
3 Dominicis feſtiſque diebus, dum conciones antemeridianae pomeridianaeue habentur in eccleſia beatae Mariae, nemo ſcholaris quocunque prętextu adeat conciones in aliis templis.

4 In templo beatae Mariae nemo infra gradum Magiſtrorum (niſi menſę Sociorum commenſalis fuerit) intrare praeſumat in aream Magiſtris deſtinatam, aut ſuperiora ex utroque areae latere ſedilia occupare.

5 Nemo galero utatur, aut in collegio, aut extra collegium; exceptis Nobilibus, & Militum primogenitis. Graduati, cum pileis ſcholaſticis, utantur etiam epitogiis: in publicis verò diſputationibus, concionibus ad clerum, ſupplicationibus, & congregationibus univerſis, habitu atque capucio (juxta ſolennem Academiae formulam) Regentes inſigniantur.

6 A congregationibus Magiſtri Regentes & Non-regentes ſeſe ne abſentent; praeſentes verò, nec diſcedant ſine venia, nec diſciplinam gravitatémque tanti Senatus, rixis, clamoribus, tranſcurſibus, conglomerationibus, aut ſubſelliorum ſcanſionibus violent. Bedelli congregationes in ſingulis collegiis ſingulas convocent, atque in collegiis ibi, ubi omnes commodè audire poſſint.
7 Sermo Latinus tantùm audiatur, tam in publicis conventibus ſcholíſque, quàm in menſis collegiorum & familiaribus colloquiis.

8 Lectores publici omnes ſtatis diebus horiſ
que diligenter praelegant: auditores lectionem aliquam ejus profeſſionis cui aſſignantur ne omittant: Decani collegiorum monitores ſeptimanatim ſingulos ſingulis ſcholis artium conſtituant: monitores, finitâ ſtatim lectione, ſchedulam abſentium exeuntiumve (pro ſuo cujuſque collegio) alteri Bedellorum tradant, ſub poena ſtatuti: Bedelli ſeptimanatim deferant ad Procancellarium, ſub virtute juramenti.

9 Inceptores, Baccalaurei, Quaeſtioniſtae, Sophiſtę omnes, Moderatores praecipuè & Diſputantes, ab omnibus invitationibus, comeſſationibus & compotationibus (tam publicis quàm privatis) omnino abſtineant, ſub poena infamię publicâ ſententiâ infligendę, & ſuſpenſionis ad annū ab omni gradu ſuſcepto & ſuſcipiendo.

10 Ad publicas Magiſtrorum diſputationes ut exeant è collegiis redeántque honeſto comitatu ſtipati, Decani collegiorum ex ſtatuto curent: Baccalaureorum atque Sophiſtarum ut interſit ſufficiens numerus, Procuratores videant.

11 In diſputationibus omnibus Magiſtrorum, Baccalaureorum, & Sophiſtarum (ſive publicè habeantur in Academia, ſive privatim in Collegiis) nulla ne
que oratio, ne
que quaeſtionum explicatio, à quoquam (Theologis, Juriſconſultis, & Medicis exceptis) de ſcripto legatur, ſub poena quinque ſolidorum, toties quoties, inter Procuratores atque Bedellos dividendorum.

12 Nemo ſcholaris (publicis privatíſque officiariis exceptis) forum frequentet, vel diutiùs in plateis moram trahat, aut in tabernas, cauponas, diverſoria, officinas pętivendulorum, aedéſve privatas (niſi juſta de cauſa per Procancellarium approbanda) ſeſe immittat.
13 Nemo ocreatus ſimul & togatus incedat: nemo canes venaticos alat, néve baliſtis utatur aut bombardis, aut retia tendat volatilibus.
14 In feſtivitate Nata •• tia nemo cum lychnis aut larvis, néve cum tubis aut tympanis exeat è collegio ſuo.
15 Nemo ſe intromittat in ſolennes conventus (quos Seſſiones aut Aſſiſas vocant) neque in electiones militum Parliamentariorum, aut in luſtrationes armorum.
16 Portae collegiorum horis ſtatutis claudantur: & nemo ſcholaris extra collegium in privatis aedibus cujuſpiam praeſumat pernoctare.

17 Quaeſtioniſtae in ſcholas à Patre ſuo producti, Praevaricatores etiam omnes, & Tripodes, & alii Diſputantes, à mimicis ſalutationibus, & rerum politicarum, magiſtratuum, aliorúmve nominationibus, à jocis quoque ſcurrilibus, à geſticulationibus, obſcoenitatibus, Anglicani ſermonis ineptiis, dicteriiſque omnibus penitùs abſtineant, ſub poena ſuſpenſionis, vel (ſi atrocitas facti poſtulaverit) expulſionis.
